content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. Section 515 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for school-based and community-based programs to prevent methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The Public Health Service Act is amended to provide grants for school-based and community-based programs to prevent methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Funds must be used for evidence-based prevention programs in districts with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. The Public Health Service Act is amended to provide grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs targeting populations at high risk for methamphetamine abuse. The Public Health Service Act is amended to provide grants for community-based prevention programs targeting populations at high risk for methamphetamine abuse, assisting local government entities in prevention activities, training law enforcement officials on signs of abuse, and supporting educational activities for prevention. The Public Health Service Act is amended to provide grants for community-based prevention programs targeting populations at high risk for methamphetamine abuse. Priority is given to rural areas for planning, administration, and educational activities related to prevention, monitoring, evaluation, and pilot programs for innovation. Not less than $500,000 of the available funds each year are allocated for analyses and evaluations of effective prevention programs for methamphetamine. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will create or adjust federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine in violation of certain acts. The United States Sentencing Commission will adjust federal sentencing guidelines for offenses involving the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine in violation of specific acts. This includes increasing the base offense level by at least 3 levels above the current level. The United States Sentencing Commission will adjust federal sentencing guidelines for offenses involving the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine by increasing the base offense level by at least 3 levels above the current level. Additionally, if the offense poses a substantial risk of danger to another person, the base offense level will be set to level 27 or higher. The base offense level for offenses involving the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine will be increased by at least 6 levels if it poses a substantial risk of danger to another person, including law enforcement officers. If the resulting base offense level would be less than 30 after the increase, it will be set to level 30. The United States Sentencing Commission will promptly implement guidelines or amendments after the enactment of this Act. Increased resources are authorized to combat methamphetamine trafficking in high-intensity drug areas, with $25 million allocated for fiscal year 1999 and additional funding for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. The amendments made by this Act will apply to offenses occurring 60 days after enactment. SEC. 4. Treatment of methamphetamine abuse. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment activities for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Grants can be made to public and non-profit entities for planning, establishing, or administering treatment programs. Grants can be used for planning, establishing, or administering methamphetamine treatment programs, including evidence-based programs, training for health professionals on recognizing methamphetamine abuse, and addiction. The Director will allocate up to $1,000,000 annually for analyses and evaluations of effective treatments for methamphetamine abuse and addiction, in consultation with other Federal agencies. The findings will be used to develop strategies for disseminating information and implementing treatment services. A report will be submitted to relevant Senate committees. The Director will allocate funds for analyses and evaluations of treatments for methamphetamine abuse. An annual report will be submitted to Senate committees. Authorization of appropriations is set at $40,000,000 for fiscal year 1999. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including studying its effects on the human body and addictive nature. Research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction includes studying the effects on the human body, addictive nature, connection to mental illness, prevention methods, treatment options, risk factors, and overall effects. Research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction includes studying risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, cultural and psychological reasons for abuse, and dissemination of research results to combat abuse. The Director will disseminate research results on methamphetamine abuse to relevant entities and there is an authorization of appropriations for funding.
